creditline: Gift of Dr. Richard L. Simmons in honor of Lotus Stack
department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: two panels; sewn together; fringe at two ends; tan, brown, off-white, rust red with touches of blue; columns of male figures holding knives (?) and severed heads; figures wear scrolling earings and headdresses; columns of figures alternate with decorative scrolling columns; striped bands on two long sides; blue and white raised chevrons at short ends
markings: in one corner, on label: TEX 2212
text: Tie-dyed Roto cloths were considered sacred by the Rongokg Toraja people of South Sulawesi, and were also traded. The neighboring Sa’dan Toraja displayed them from tall bamboo poles as banners at rituals, especially the funerals of high-ranking people. The vibrant, halo-effect of the three-colored diamonds is achieved by loosely tying the cloth during the dyeing process. The patters of larger and smaller dots are sometimes though of as a constellation of stars. Here, one can make out a snake and human figures within the tricolored bands.
title: Ceremonial textile (pua)
